dataset.title: Social Biology of the Bushy-tailed Woodrat, Neotoma cinerea

creator.organizationName: University of California Natural Reserve System

abstract.para: DOCTORATE DISSERTATION: The social biology of Neotoma cinerea was examined in the field, laboratory, and museum...Over 1000 museum specimens were analyzed in series and by sex and age classes. A laboratory population was maintained and bred for behavioral observations. A field study, at Sagehen Creek in the Sierra Nevada, gave information on social organization.

additionalInfo.para: * The temporal dates given refer to dates spent in the field.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: FIELD: The Sagehen Creek Field Station ... is located on the east slope of the northern Sierra Nevada, eight miles NNW of Truckee, Nevada County, California, and is at an elevation of 6400 ft.

section.title: Methods
section.para: MUSEUM: For each of 1000 specimens, data was recorded from the label, skins examined, individuals aged, and field notes referenced.
LAB: A laboratory colony of bushy-tails was established (and bred) in Berkeley for behavioral observations.
FIELD: Live trapping of marked populations, supplemented with radiotracking (collars) of certain populations and urine mark surveys were employed.

description.para: FIELD: From Nov, 1970 through Sept, 1974, researcher spent 155 days in the field studying bushy-tails.

samplingDescription.para: FIELD: Locations for individual traps were decided by the intensity of fresh urine marking, the presence of apparent dens, and prior trapping success at a given location.
